title: Chorea Evaluation
icd10: G25.0 (Essential tremor — when chorea is considered)
scope: ** Systematic evaluation of chorea in adults and adolescents. Covers the differential diagnosis approach to chorea including hereditary (Huntington disease, HD phenocopies), autoimmune (Sydenham, SLE, antiphospholipid syndrome), drug-induced (tardive, dopaminergic), metabolic (thyrotoxicosis, Wilson disease, hyper/hypoglycemia), vascular (post-stroke), and paraneoplastic etiologies. Includes treatment with VMAT2 inhibitors and symptomatic management. Excludes tardive dyskinesia as primary diagnosis (covered separately).

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology (movement disorders specialist) for diagnostic classification, VMAT2 inhibitor management, and long-term chorea suppression
Genetic counseling BEFORE Huntington disease gene testing (mandatory; informed consent for implications for family, insurance, and reproductive planning)
Rheumatology if autoimmune chorea suspected (SLE, antiphospholipid syndrome) for systemic disease management
Hepatology if Wilson disease diagnosed for liver disease management and transplant evaluation if needed
Cardiology for echocardiogram if Sydenham chorea or rheumatic fever suspected (rheumatic heart disease screening)
Psychiatry for management of depression, psychosis, irritability, and suicidality especially in Huntington disease
Endocrinology if hyperglycemic chorea for long-term diabetes management and glucose optimization
Physical therapy for balance, gait, and fall prevention; adaptive movement strategies
Occupational therapy for adaptive equipment, home safety assessment, and activities of daily living support
Speech therapy for dysarthria and dysphagia assessment, especially in HD; swallowing evaluation before discharge
Oncology if paraneoplastic chorea diagnosed (CRMP5, CASPR2 antibodies) for malignancy workup and treatment
Social work for care coordination, advance directive planning, disability resources, and family support in HD

Patient Instructions.item: Report new or worsening depression, suicidal thoughts, or mood changes immediately while on VMAT2 inhibitors (tetrabenazine has BLACK BOX WARNING for suicidality)
Use fall precautions at home and in hospital; chorea increases fall risk especially with gait involvement; use handrails, non-slip footwear
Return to ED if chorea suddenly worsens, new weakness develops, speech/swallowing difficulty appears, or signs of stroke occur
Do not stop chorea medications abruptly; sudden withdrawal of dopamine-blocking agents can cause withdrawal dyskinesia or rebound chorea
Genetic counseling is mandatory before and after Huntington disease testing due to implications for family members, insurance, and reproductive planning
Take VMAT2 inhibitors with food for better absorption (deutetrabenazine requires food); report any difficulty swallowing pills
Maintain adequate fluid and caloric intake; HD patients have increased metabolic demand due to involuntary movements and are at risk for malnutrition
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery until chorea severity is assessed and medication side effects (sedation, parkinsonism) are stable
Carry a medical alert identification if diagnosed with Huntington disease or if on anticoagulation for antiphospholipid syndrome
Report new involuntary movements, stiffness, tremor, or restlessness that could indicate medication side effects (EPS, parkinsonism, akathisia)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Home safety evaluation to remove sharp edges, pad furniture, and reduce fall hazards given involuntary movements
Caloric intake monitoring in HD (chorea increases metabolic demand by 500-1000 kcal/day; weight loss is common and associated with worse outcomes)
Advance care planning early in HD course while decision-making capacity is preserved; designate healthcare proxy
Support groups: Huntington's Disease Society of America (HDSA) for patients and families with HD; local and online resources
Avoid medications that worsen chorea: dopamine agonists, levodopa, stimulants, anticholinergics (review all medications at each visit)
Regular aerobic exercise (adapted to chorea severity) to improve mood, endurance, and cardiovascular health; supervised physical activity preferred
Stress management with relaxation techniques as stress and fatigue exacerbate chorea severity
Adequate sleep hygiene; sleep deprivation worsens chorea and cognitive function in HD
Limit alcohol use; alcohol interacts with benzodiazepines and VMAT2 inhibitors; Wilson disease patients must avoid alcohol

differential.features: Family history (autosomal dominant); progressive chorea + cognitive decline + psychiatric symptoms; caudate atrophy on MRI
differential.tests: HTT gene testing (≥36 CAG repeats); MRI (caudate atrophy); family history

differential.features: History of dopamine receptor blocking agent exposure; orofacial predominance (lip-smacking, tongue movements); may involve limbs
differential.tests: Medication history (antipsychotics, metoclopramide); AIMS scale; onset after ≥3 months of neuroleptic exposure

differential.features: Children/adolescents; preceded by streptococcal infection; self-limiting (months); associated with rheumatic fever
differential.tests: ASO titer; anti-DNase B; echocardiogram (rheumatic heart disease); Jones criteria

differential.features: Young women; other SLE features (rash, arthritis, nephritis); antiphospholipid antibodies often positive
differential.tests: ANA; anti-dsDNA; antiphospholipid antibodies; complement C3/C4; lupus diagnostic criteria

differential.features: Chorea with thrombotic events; may occur without SLE; lupus anticoagulant positive
differential.tests: Antiphospholipid antibodies (lupus anticoagulant, anti-cardiolipin, anti-β2GP1); thrombotic history

differential.features: Age <50; liver disease; psychiatric symptoms; Kayser-Fleischer rings; dystonia often coexists
differential.tests: Ceruloplasmin (low); 24-hr urine copper (elevated); slit-lamp exam (KF rings); genetic testing (ATP7B)

differential.features: Elderly; acute hemichorea/hemiballismus; very high blood glucose; T1 hyperintensity in contralateral putamen on MRI
differential.tests: Blood glucose (often >400 mg/dL); MRI (T1 hyperintensity in basal ganglia); HbA1c; resolves with glucose normalization

differential.features: Acute onset; hemiballismus or hemichorea; contralateral subthalamic or basal ganglia lesion
differential.tests: MRI brain (infarct in subthalamic nucleus, striatum, or thalamus); vascular risk factors

differential.features: Temporal relationship to medication (levodopa, dopamine agonists, stimulants, anticonvulsants, OCP)
differential.tests: Medication reconciliation; resolution with drug discontinuation or dose reduction

differential.features: Subacute onset; weight loss; smoking history; CRMP5 or CASPR2 antibodies; may have other neurologic features
differential.tests: Paraneoplastic antibody panel; CT chest/abdomen/pelvis; PET/CT

differential.features: Orofacial chorea with lip/tongue biting; feeding dystonia; seizures; elevated CK; acanthocytes on blood smear
differential.tests: Peripheral blood smear (acanthocytes); CK (elevated); VPS13A gene testing

differential.features: Childhood onset; non-progressive; thyroid and pulmonary abnormalities may be present; NKX2-1 mutations
differential.tests: NKX2-1/TITF1 gene testing; thyroid function; chest imaging; non-progressive course

differential.features: Chorea as rare manifestation; erythrocytosis; splenomegaly; JAK2 mutation
differential.tests: CBC (elevated Hgb/Hct); JAK2 V617F mutation; EPO level

evidence.recommendation: Deutetrabenazine reduces chorea in Huntington disease (FIRST-HD and ARC-HD trials)
Tetrabenazine reduces chorea in Huntington disease (TETRA-HD trial)
VMAT2 inhibitors: tetrabenazine BLACK BOX WARNING for depression and suicidality
Non-ketotic hyperglycemic hemichorea: glucose correction resolves symptoms
AAN practice guideline on pharmacologic treatment of chorea in HD
Sydenham chorea management per rheumatic fever guidelines
Antiphospholipid syndrome-associated chorea responds to immunosuppression and anticoagulation

disposition.criteria: Mild chorea without acute metabolic cause; stable hemodynamics; no swallowing risk; outpatient neurology follow-up arranged; offending medication identified and addressed

New-onset severe chorea requiring urgent workup; hyperglycemic chorea requiring insulin management; suspected autoimmune or paraneoplastic chorea needing expedited workup; hemiballismus from acute stroke; Wilson disease with hepatic decompensation
Severe ballismus causing injury or exhaustion; chorea with aspiration pneumonia and respiratory failure; status epilepticus; Wilson disease with acute liver failure
All patients with chronic chorea: q3-6 months; Huntington disease: multidisciplinary HD clinic q3-6 months; medication titration: q2-4 weeks
Required BEFORE Huntington gene testing; post-test counseling for positive results
